ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Elementary python skills from functions, to classes and objects, to data science and visualization

- Python
- Data Science
- Fundamental Programming Paradigms
I learned fundamental Python skillsets that I will be able to apply to various data & analytics problems in my career.

I had zero Python or data science experience coming into this class. Leaving the course, I can say with confidence that I have literacy in Python, now able to complete basic functions that my social science research may require, and that I understand the fundamentals of machine learning. I think that there are few courses at Yale where you can truly go from knowing nothing at the beginning of the semester to feeling relatively fluent in a topic by the end o the semester.
I learned about the fundamentals of computer science and there applications to data analysis during this class.
I learned how to use python and apply it to my interests. I wish this course could count for S&DS too, since our final project was very data science-focused.
I learned a lot about the foundations of Python and how to use it to visualize data. Professor was great at incorporating the social sciences and humanities into the data science units.
I finally learned Python which I have been wanting to learn for a long time. I also built basic coding and algorithmic skills!
Coding knowledge and practical experience
I learned how to code in Python, create visualizations, and answer questions using Python.
How to code in python and use it for data analysis!
Python basic skills, concepts for programming.

Basic-to-intermediate python programming skills, including commonly used libraries like Pandas, Numpy, Seaborn, etc. Knowledge of data science (i.e., data cleaning, analysis, graphing, regression, interpretation) methods. Insights into classification machine learning techniques. Presentation skills.
How to code in Python, how to carry out preliminary statistics, how to reason through coding PSETs.
basic skills in Python, introduction to coding, data science and visualization skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Great course; Prof Park is really great, wants everyone to do well and does everything in her power to make sure that that happens
Covers a lot of ground quickly, which makes it a bit difficult
Lecture slides are organized, learn a lot of content, problem sets are good, office hours very very available
The course was extremely comprehensive.

Strengths: accessibility of materials; number of office hours; walkthrough videos for homework; coding sessions alongside the professor in class; breadth of knowledge covered; a professor who cares
Weaknesses: I think some of the more difficult topics at the beginning in Python were maybe rushed (sometimes we wouldn't finish in-class coding exercises), but we would use an entire class to go over ethics in CS; while I think ethics and other topics covered later in the class were important, those lectures maybe should have been beefed up or we should have cut them to half a class so we had more time to learn the intricacies of classes, for ex.

Strengths: Conformative to whatever needs you have for your learning style, office hours every week, willingness to help

Weaknesses: High tempo / Pace

Strengths: office hours, there were 15 hours of office hours and all the ULAs and Professor helped a lot every week for the psets. The homeworks were just challenging enough so it was doable and made you learn. 
Weakness: there was a lot of material and classwork psets to cover during one class so it felt rushed at times and hard to keep up. but as long as you grasp the key concepts, you should be able to do the hw psets.

Poorly designed syllabus, too ambitious, sought to cover both intro CS and data science. Instructor ended up rushing through every lecture in the second half of the course and gave no time for students to process new information/actually understand the topics. Badly taught lectures.

Structured course with supportive professor and TAs
Would be better if more in class exercise provided (or more detailed instructions on in class exercise)

Strengths: I could go to office hours and be helped consistently. The class taught you a lot about Python in a useful way and did not assume any prior knowledge. 

Weakness: it was a bit fast paced for those in the humanities.

Strengths: Dr. Park truly wants you to succeed and dedicates so much of her time to making helpful resources 

Weaknesses: The data science part of the course seemed to pop out of nowhere and was a bit difficult to really grasp if you have no prior stats knowledge
The pace was very fast in the second half of the course, but the professor was very kind.

Strengths: very kind, empathetic, smart, and talented professor who clearly cares a lot about her students. Very well-prepared lecture/module materials that gave students very helpful references to well-written python code.

To improve: better paced lectures to optimize learning of students. Less pop-up quizzes completed during class (as opposed to before class starts). More time going through code lectures as opposed to PowerPoint slides. Better pacing to integrate data science methods relatively earlier in class to not backload as much.

Strengths: Amazingly committed Professor, Sohee cares a lot and is willing to go the extra mile everytime. Weaknesses: This time around there were a lot of things still being figured out in running the class so there was sometimes confusion and I would say the final project has too many tasks and components to it. Regardless, you'll still learn a lot.

Concepts should be taught more in-depth in class, things are gone over very quickly and you need to go to a lot of office hours to actually understand what's happening in the class/do well on the p-sets. The final project had way too many components and wasn't well structured so I didn't feel like I knew what I was doing and ended up credit/d-ing the class because grading wasn't posted so I didn't know how I was doing over all.

weaknesses- the psets were hard/time consuming at the beginning of the course
strengths- tons of room for extra credit

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: 100%, especially for folks who want to take a CS class and get a good grade
Yep, gives you a good intro to Python in a chill environment
I would highly recommend this course.

If you want to learn Python, this course is the one to take. The professor deeply cares about student learning and wants to ensure that you are successful in the class. There are ample opportunities for extra credit, and the assignments are not overly difficult. There are few courses where you enter knowing so little and can exit knowing so much.
Yes, it's challenging if you don't have a computer science background. however, I liked the way this made me get outside of my comfort zone
Yes! The first half of the class you learn how to use python and the other half you develop your own model (ex. classification or prediction)
Yes, if you are interested in cs or data science, taking this course kind of kills two birds with one stone. python is the easiest language so learning that first can help.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn Python, regardless of their major. Yale was lacking a good intro to Python class and this is it!
No. NOT a good intro CS experience.
Yes! Good course for DS intro.
I would recommend if you want to learn about coding in a practical way. I know feel confident to use this knowledge for my thesis or further study!

Yes! I was apprehensive but I think I walked away from this course with a new understanding of all the capabilities of Python and coding for disciplines that you might not automatically assume would benefit from it.
yes, I understand it's the professor's first class at Yale. She might need more time to adjust and adapt. She is a very kind person and I like her very much.

Yes. The professors passion is amazing. While there are still a few kinks to work out with the curriculum, overall its a fantastic learning experience for anyone interested in using Python for the social sciences.

Yes! Absolutely it's a great introduction to coding and data science and was really fun. I will say that a huge caveat is that it was a bit overwhelming for people who had never done stats or had any coding experience, so keep in mind that it will be more work in that case, but I still think it is a better/easier introduction than CS 50 or some of the other options out there.
yes if you're interested on a basic level intro to the field of computer science (and data science)

extras.title: CPSC 110 01 - Python Prog for Hum & Soc Svcs
